Title: Surrender
Summary:
With Vadic in control of the Titan’s bridge and many crewmembers held hostage, Picard and his allies must find a way to retake the ship before it reaches Frontier Day. Vadic uses the internal comms to taunt the crew, demanding that Jack surrender himself to her in exchange for their lives. Jack, increasingly confident in his psychic-link abilities, considers accepting her offer to end the bloodshed.

In the ship’s systems, Data and Lore engage in a metaphysical struggle for control of their shared body and the Titan’s computers. Geordi and his daughters watch Data’s memories flash by as he deliberately gives Lore access to treasured moments, overwhelming Lore with the very humanity he once rejected. Ultimately, Data’s strategy succeeds, allowing him to reclaim full control and help the crew sever Vadic’s hold, leading to a decisive confrontation in open space.

StorySections.Text: Vadic paces the Titan’s bridge, broadcasting messages throughout the ship that blend mockery with threats. She announces that unless Jack surrenders, she will begin executing hostages.

Jack, guilt-ridden over the danger to the crew, proposes giving himself up to Vadic. Beverly and Picard argue that doing so would only hand their enemies an even more powerful weapon. Seven and Shaw coordinate quiet resistance efforts from their limited positions.

In the lab, Geordi interfaces with the android, watching as Data and Lore share memories. Lore initially seems to be winning, deleting Data’s cherished recollections one by one. Geordi realizes that Data is willingly surrendering his "possessions" as part of a deeper plan.

Jack uses his abilities to briefly inhabit another crewmember, scouting Vadic’s positions on the ship. He sees glimpses of her past and senses her connection to the experiments conducted on Changelings. The experience rattles him but also gives him insight into her vulnerabilities.

Data’s gambit pays off: by giving Lore all his memories, he forces Lore to experience genuine affection, friendship, and loss, destabilizing his identity. Lore ultimately cannot destroy what he has absorbed and dissolves into Data’s consciousness, leaving Data whole again. With control restored, Data helps open bulkheads and override systems, enabling the crew to retake key sections of the ship.

The crew lures Vadic and her forces toward an airlock. In a final standoff, they vent her and her minions into space, where Vadic freezes and shatters against the Titan’s hull. Despite this victory, Picard knows that the larger threat to Starfleet remains—and that Jack’s true nature is still unresolved.

EntitySummaries.Jean-Luc Picard: Picard must balance his instinct to protect Jack with his responsibility to the Titan’s crew, refusing to allow his son to sacrifice himself too easily. His reliance on Data and his old crew underscores the strength of their decades-long bonds.
EntitySummaries.Data: Data demonstrates profound growth by using vulnerability and generosity to defeat Lore, rather than brute force. His reclaimed identity blends his past experiences with a newfound sense of completeness.
EntitySummaries.Geordi La Forge: Geordi acts as emotional anchor during Data and Lore’s internal struggle, trusting that his friend’s humanity will prevail. His faith is rewarded when Data emerges whole.
EntitySummaries.Jack Crusher: Jack continues to wrestle with the moral implications of his powers and the temptation to trade his freedom for others’ safety. His brief mental contact with Vadic deepens his fear that he may be fundamentally different from other humans.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven remains defiant under Vadic’s occupation, coordinating subtle resistance efforts and supporting Shaw. Her experience with assimilation and control makes her particularly attuned to the crew’s psychological state.
EntitySummaries.Vadic: Vadic reaches the height of her power aboard the Titan but underestimates the crew’s resilience and Data’s return. Her death removes a major antagonist but leaves her masters’ broader plan intact.
EntitySummaries.Lore: Lore’s final defeat comes not from deletion but from absorption into Data’s more balanced self. His legacy lives on as part of Data’s complex identity.
EntitySummaries.Beverly Crusher: Beverly stands firm against the idea of sacrificing Jack, even as she acknowledges the danger his powers pose. Her fierceness as a mother continues to guide her decisions.
EntitySummaries.Captain Liam Shaw: Shaw remains sarcastic and combative in the face of occupation, yet his tactical instincts and willingness to fight back help the crew endure. His begrudging respect for the old Enterprise crew grows as they retake the ship.

Serves as a turning point where the Titan regains agency ahead of the Frontier Day climax.

Title: Võx
Summary:
With Vadic defeated, the Titan races to warn Starfleet about the impending threat at Frontier Day. Deanna Troi helps Jack confront the recurring red door in his mind, leading to a devastating revelation: the door opens onto the Borg Collective, and Jack is a transmitter for a new form of assimilation signal encoded in his genes by Picard’s time as Locutus. Jack realizes that his visions and powers have been the Borg’s influence all along.

At the Frontier Day ceremony, an enhanced Starfleet transporter system—tainted by Changeling modifications—activates a hidden Borg code in the young officers’ DNA, instantly assimilating them into a new kind of collective without implants. The fleet’s ships, all networked under a unified system, fall under Borg control. Shaw is killed helping Seven and Raffi escape in the Titan’s shuttle, while the original Enterprise-D crew reunites at the Fleet Museum to take their old ship into one last mission to stop the Borg and save Jack.

StorySections.Text: Deanna Troi arrives aboard the Titan and embraces Riker, reuniting the couple amid crisis. She agrees to help Picard and Beverly probe Jack’s mind to understand the source of his powers.

In a joint counseling session, Troi guides Jack through his recurring vision of the red door and whispering voices. When the door finally opens, Jack finds himself face-to-face with the Borg Queen’s presence, realizing his connection to the Collective. Picard is horrified to learn that residual Borg code in his own altered DNA was passed on to his son.

Frontier Day begins with Admiral Shelby unveiling the new Fleet Formation system, which allows Starfleet ships to move as a single coordinated armada. Unbeknownst to her, the Changelings and Borg have corrupted the system. As transporters cycle personnel, a buried genetic modification activates in officers below a certain age.

Young officers across the fleet, including many on the Titan, suddenly begin speaking with Borg-inflected voices and turn their weapons on older crewmembers. Starships under their control pivot to attack dissenters and seal off escape routes. Seven, Shaw, and Raffi fight to free as many non-assimilated crew as they can.

Shaw is mortally wounded while covering Seven and Raffi’s escape, finally acknowledging Seven by her chosen name and affirming her as a true Starfleet captain in spirit. Picard, Beverly, Riker, Troi, Worf, Geordi, and Data regroup at the Fleet Museum, where Geordi reveals he has secretly restored the Enterprise-D using parts from other ships. The old crew boards their beloved ship, ready to face the Borg one last time.

Jack, unable to bear the thought of being used as a weapon, steals a shuttle and flies to the Borg signal’s source to confront the Queen directly. Aboard the Enterprise-D, Picard vows to bring his son home and stop the Borg, whatever the cost.

Title: The Last Generation
Summary:
In the climactic confrontation, the reunited Enterprise-D crew flies their resurrected ship into the heart of a vast Borg structure hidden in Jupiter’s atmosphere, where the Borg Queen is using Jack as a nexus to control the assimilated Starfleet armada. Picard leads an away team with Riker and Worf to infiltrate the Borg cube, while Geordi and Data pilot the Enterprise-D through deadly defenses. Their objective is to free Jack and destroy the signal controlling the young officers before the armada annihilates Earth and key Federation worlds.

Aboard the Titan, now under Seven and Raffi’s leadership, the remaining unassimilated crew fights to protect as many civilians and older officers as possible from the rampaging fleet. Picard enters the Borg network mentally to reach Jack, confronting his own past as Locutus and offering unconditional love and acceptance instead of commands. Together they sever the Queen’s control, causing the assimilated officers to regain themselves just as the Enterprise-D escapes a collapsing cube. In the aftermath, Starfleet begins to rebuild, the TNG-era crew shares a final celebration, and Picard looks toward the future with Jack and his old friends at his side.

StorySections.Text: Narration recalls pivotal moments from Starfleet’s history as the assimilated fleet closes in on Earth. The Enterprise-D emerges from warp, a symbol of an earlier generation returning for one last stand.

The Enterprise-D locates the Borg structure within Jupiter, revealing a decayed but still dangerous cube sustained by the Queen’s will. Picard, Riker, and Worf beam aboard to find Jack, while Geordi, Data, and Troi manage the ship. Worf arrives heavily armed, blending his spiritual calm with characteristic bravado.

On the Titan, Seven and Raffi coordinate a resistance movement among unassimilated crew and civilians, using guerrilla tactics to disable key ship systems under Borg control. They work to protect Sidney, Alandra, and others while buying time for the Enterprise-D’s mission. The cost in lives is high, but morale is anchored by Seven’s leadership.

Inside the cube, Picard finds Jack fully integrated into a Borg node, calling himself "Võx"—the voice of the Borg. The Queen reveals her plan to use this new generation of assimilated officers as the "last generation" needed to secure total victory. Worf and Riker battle drones while Picard chooses to connect to the Collective rather than destroy Jack’s node from the outside.

Within the Borg mental landscape, Picard reaches Jack not as an admiral but as a father, sharing memories, regrets, and love. He tells Jack that he would rather remain with him in the Collective than leave him alone in darkness. Jack, moved by his father’s vulnerability and acceptance, chooses to step away from the Queen’s control and disconnect.

With Jack freed, the control signal collapses and the assimilated officers across the fleet regain themselves, allowing Seven and Raffi to reclaim the Titan. The Enterprise-D narrowly escapes the cube’s self-destruction and returns in triumph. In the aftermath, Picard shares a poker game with his old crew in a final, heartfelt farewell, while a closing epilogue shows Jack assigned to a new starship under Seven’s command, hinting at adventures yet to come.
